description: From Middle English nausea, a borrowing from Latin nausea, from Ancient Greek ναυσία (nausía, “sea-sickness”), from ναῦς (naûs, “ship”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)neh₂-. Displaced native Old English wlǣtta.

nouns.description: nausea (countable and uncountable, plural nauseas or nauseae or nauseæ)

entries.meaning: A feeling of illness or discomfort in the digestive system, usually characterized by a strong urge to vomit.
